entry.title: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the S/4HANA Public Edition (Pt B:Joule Installation)
entry.content:
Introduction

Now Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on every professional‚Äôs mind. Everybody wants to be on the bandwagon.  I plan to write a series of blogs on this topic under a big umbrella ‚ÄúMy AI Experience Sharing‚Äù.  This is the first mini-series: setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

I purposely delayed my action on setting up a Joule to wait for the dust settling down during the Early Adopter phase. The intention paid off but still won‚Äôt give me a free pass üòâ. There are five credible references available as listed in the Reference section, but none of them give you a good explanation on Why, especially on What in a critical step with a readable picture when you desperately need a hint.  To help all the people like me, this blog will focus on explaining those steps, what to enter, and possible mistakes to avoid. 

Note 1: The content here is drawn from my direct experience from setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (more than five times and still counting). It might be true for other SAP solutions but only use that as a reference so that I don‚Äôt feel the pressure of entire SAP world on my shoulder üòÅ.

Note 2: Since there are a lot of topics to discuss, I divided the mini-series into Part A Preparation,  Part B Joule Installation and Part C Deinstallation. 

Note 3: The systems I used in this mini-series are:

  • BTP Global Account: 2024-09 3SL Account
  • BTP Joule Subaccount: PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Production tenant G4X/100, http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/ 
  • Cloud Identity Services: Provisioned together with above BTP and Public Cloud tenants, xxxxxxxx.accounts.ondemand.com

Note 4: Considering some customers and consultants need to deinstall and reinstall Joule for many reasons like practicing the installation, correcting an unsuccessful installation, etc., I am adding a new blog Part C: Deinstallation here for your reference.

 

Ten Major Joule Installation Steps Explained

In this section, I am going to explain all ten Joule Installation Steps.  The hyperlink of each step gives a direct access to the document.

We can group Joule Installation Steps into four categories:

  • Step B.1: Run Joule Booster
  • Steps B.2 ‚Äì B.4: Validate the results of running Joule Booster, make some updates accordingly.
  • Steps B.5 ‚Äì B.9: Setup an infrastructure and provision/replicate users/groups from the Public Cloud to the Work Zone
  • Step B.10: Test your Joule

 

Step B.1 DC1: Run Booster in SAP BTP for Joule

Within SAP BTP, there is a concept called formation, which is a logical grouping of SAP systems, specifically designed for event sharing within a business scenario.  The Joule Booster groups four systems into one formation for the business scenario of Running Joule on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: SAP Cloud Identity Services, SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP Build Work Zone, and Joule.  Refer to the picture in Step B.2.1 Check the Formation Created by the Joule Booster.

The Joule Booster is to automate the formation creation process, including communication related infrastructure. Here is the final Review page before executing the Joule Booster.

Review Page of the Joule Booster

Note: From April 9, 2025, our BTP colleagues made an improvement in the Joule Booster. Now there are two versions available, "Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)" and "Setting Up Joule". The former one is for SAP internal setup usage, and later one is for customers and partners.  There are different entitlement requirements for each of them.  I waited one entitlement for weeks to run the "Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)".  Hope this won‚Äôt be the case for you.

 

Step B.2 Post Booster Configuration

At the end of Discovery Center Establish a Unified Joule Instance and the beginning of Discovery Center Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are two very similar steps: Post Booster Configuration for the former, and Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution for the later. Some work is redundant, but you need to follow Post Booster Configuration first, then Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution.  Because there are critical steps in Post Booster Configuration to create NavigationService destination, etc. 

In one installation exercise, I tried to launch the Work Zone link in the Instances and Subscriptions, I got an error message: "Uh oh‚Ä¶We can‚Äôt seem to find the site that you‚Äôre looking for. Either the site doesn‚Äôt exist or it‚Äôs temporarily unavailable.‚Äù  The reason is that the system needs to use the Portal Service URL definition stored in the NavigationService destination to access https://portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/resources/portal/sap/cf/pages/siteNotFound/siteNotFound.html. 

B.2.1 Check the Formation Created by the Joule Booster.

Within the Joule formation, all four systems should be included (shown in the picture of above).

The BTP Formation for the Joule Running on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Depending on your business needs, you can add another SAP solution into it.  For example, if you add a SuccessFactors system here, both SuccessFactors and Public Cloud share the same Joule.

B.2.2 Check Joule Subscription and Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount

Joule subscription was created as part of the Joule Booster execution.  This step is to test a user can logon to the Joule application.  The URL is like this https://pscc-amer-3sl-prd-xxxxxxxx.eu12.sapdas.cloud.sap/. As you can see in this string, the first part is my subaccount name PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD. The second part xxxxxxxx is the Joule‚Äôs system ID (partially).  The last part is the subdomain.  In the Post Booster Configuration, it was listed as ‚Äú4m8qi0do‚Äù. The last part indicates the data center is located in Europe (e12), and it is a Joule system (sapdas).

Note: when you launch the Joule application for the first time here, a new user with a cryptic ID is created (see the user discussion in Step B.3.2 Content Provider). That's another reason Step B.2 needs to be executed before B.3.

B.2.3 Check If Destinations Are Created Successfully

In Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution, it lists six destinations.  In my case, only four destinations are created by the Joule Booster as shown in the picture.  There are no Navigation Service nor Runtime destinations there as described

  • Design Time Destination - (with _dt in the name)
  • Runtime Destinations (Not there)
  • Runtime Data (with _rt_data in the name)
  • Runtime Default (with _rt_default in the name)
  • S4HANA_PUB_SSO
  • Navigation Service (Not there yet. Wasn‚Äôt created automatically)

Four Destinations Created by the Joule Booster

B.2.4 Create NavigationService Destination

To complete this step, we need to use the Service Key created in the Step A.7 Create SAP Build Work Zone Instance and Subscription.  My NavigationSerivce definition is shown below as a reference.

NavigationService Properties

For your convenience, I am listing the entry mapping between Service Content Key and the NavigationService definition.

Work Zone Service Key File Content

Navigation Service Properties

Notes

 

Name: NavigationService

 
 

Type: HTTP

 
 

Description: can be anything

 
 

Proxy Type: Internet

 

‚Äúportal ‚Äì service‚Äù

URL

Including https://

 

Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange

 

‚Äúclientid‚Äù

Client ID

 

‚Äúclientsecret‚Äù

Client Secret

Add /oauth/token toward the end of the string, with leading https://

 

After saving the destination, click on the button Check Connection.  I got an error 404 in the first time.  This indicates a web page cannot be found.

Error 404 when Checking Navigation Service Connection

There are two URL‚Äôs in the destination definition.  The first one is https://portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com.  When I enter it in a Web Browser, it returns 404 error:

               404 Not Found: Requested route ('portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com') does not exist.

This NavigationService is a mystery to me.  In the Solution Architecture diagram (see the beginning of the Part A Preparation Blog), there is a Navigation Target Mapping within the BTP box.  It is used by the Work Zone to fetch roles and available navigational targets, kind of like a look up table. Therefore you don't execute this connection directly. 

At the beginning of Step B.2, I presented an error message due to the absence of NavationService destination. 

The second URL is the Token Service URL. That one works when posting directly in a Web Browser.

B.2.5 Update Application Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service

This step is to verify two applications created by the Joule Booster das-ias and Document Grounding have the same Conditional Authentication setting.

In below figure, although there is no subaccount name as part of the das-ias application, but the number 2199220a appears in all three applications: das-ias, Document Grounding, and SAP BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD. I can comfortably conclude that applications das-ias and Document Grounding are Joule related for my subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD.

Three Joule Related Applications in the SAP CIS

All three applications have the same Conditional Authentication setting using Identity Authentication. Joule Booster did a good job!

B.2.6 Update Trusted Domains Settings

This setting is also in the SAP CIS. We already completed it in Step A.6 Blog1: 7.2 Trust the Public Cloud Tenant Domain in SAP Cloud Identity Services.

 

Step B.3 DC2: Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution

B.3.1 Check SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount

This step is the same as B.2.3 Check If Destinations Are Created Successfully.

B.3.2 Check Content Provider in the SAP Work Zone

The purpose of this step is to find out the name of the Work Zone Channel Content Provider which we will use for later (Step B.8).

In the BTP Cockpit -> Security -> Users, usually you can see a pair of users with the same Username but different Identity Provider.  For example, my name is listed twice: one with a temporary cryptic ID (also called IAS shadow user ID) and another with my email address.  The cryptic user ID is created/updated on the fly when you access the SAP Work Zone or Joule.  During Joule Setup, this cryptic ID is created in Step B.2.2 Check Joule Subscription and Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount when you launch the Joule application.  Its Identity Provider is the SAP Cloud ID Service or IAS.  My last Work Zone logon time is May 23. 

The email address username is used for logon to BTP tenant.   It uses the Default Identity Provider and shows May 27 because I logged on to the BTP on May 27.

Two Parallel Users in the BTP User List

There are six sub-steps listed in the document. I‚Äôd like to explain some of these steps:

Steps 1-3: The SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition is the new name for the SAP Launchpad service. So, you will still see the name of Launchpad here and there.  The reason of assigning the Launchpad_Admin role to the cryptic User ID is to prepare this user to access the SAP Build Work Zone as an administrator to read its Content Provider name.  Without this user role, your access to the Work Zone will be denied.

Step 5: This step is to logon to the Work Zone as an Administrator with your username and the password stored in the IAS. The user must have the Launchpad_Admin role assigned.

When you launch the Work Zone, pay attention to the URL: https://pscc-amer-3sl-prd-xxxxxxxx.dt.launchpad.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/sites#Site-Directory.  It is in fact the URL in your Service Key file, and you entered it during NavigationService creation in Step B.2.4. 

Step 6: The Content Provider ID will be used in the SAP Cloud Identity Provisioning setup (Step B.9).  It will be part of many names I will point it out later.

 

Step B.4 DC2: Validate and Update S/4HANA Cloud Configuration after Joule Booster Execution

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the integration with other SAP solutions is predefined according to the scenarios, that includes the integration with the BTP. 

For each integration scenario, we have one specific Communication Arrangement defined, which in turn depends on the underlying Communication System.  One Communication System can support one or more Communication Arrangement(s), but not the other way around.  If you want two same type of Communication Arrangement integrates to two solutions, you need to create two different Communication Arrangements (different names but the same type) residing on two different Communication Systems.

Here are two Communication Arrangements for Joule setup:

  • SAP_COM_0647 for Launchpad Content Exposure to SAP BTP Integration
  • SAP_COM_0882 for SAP Digital Assistant Services

Since the Communication Arrangements are created by the Joule Booster, they all use cryptic ID instead of readable names. Sometimes you might have multiple of them. The easiest way to identify the right one is to check its creation/changing date when you run the Joule Booster.

The Joule Booster creates four Communication Systems. Two are used for the above two Communication Systems. The other two Communication Systems are not used by any Communication Arrangements.  I don‚Äôt know why Joule Booster creates them.  If you have an insight on them, please comment!

 

Step B.5 DC2: Configure S/4HANA Cloud for User Replication with Identity Provisioning Service

Steps B.5 though B.9 are for provisioning users and roles from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to the SAP Work Zone instance.  This is very similar as we provision users from the IAS to the Central Business Configuration in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as I discussed in my blog Deep Dive into the CBC User Authentication and Authorization Concept.

Let me give a quick explanation (referring below figure). SAP Work Zone is a service running on the SAP BTP.  It does not create users and assign user roles within itself. However, when you access Joule (through Work Zone), you are still limited to those apps you have authorizations to access. This is achieved by doing an authorization check within the Work Zone.

Concept of User/Group Provisioning for the SAP Work Zone

To provision users and corresponding roles from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we need to prepare a user provisioning infrastructure manually here.  In comparison, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition has this infrastructure provisioned by the operations team during system provisioning.

Step B.5 is to set up the Identity Provisioning infrastructure, namely the Communication Arrangement and the Communication System. 

Take a note of the newly created Inbound Communication User, including the username and the password. We will use them in Step B.7.  If this Communication User is locked after multiple logon failures, you won‚Äôt be able to provision users/groups to Work Zone again, for example, after you add new users and add/remove user roles.

 

Step B.6 DC2: Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud

This step is to add the URL of the Joule application to the Trusted Sites list of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition via application Manage Content Security Policy.  This way the Joule can run as an add-on to the Public Cloud and access all of its data and applications.

You can obtain your Joule application URL by going to BTP ÔÉ† Your Subaccount ÔÉ† Services ÔÉ† Instances and Subscriptions ÔÉ† Subscriptions ÔÉ† Application ÔÉ† Clicking on the Joule hyperlink.

Add the Joule URL to the Trusted Site List

 

Step B.7 DC2: Configure Identity Provisioning Service for User Replication to Work Zone

This Step is to make Identity Provisioning Service working.  You do the following:

  • Configure SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as a Source System in Identity Provisioning
  • Configure SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition as a Target System in Identity Provisioning

The following figure displays The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud as a New Source System in the SAP CIS.  The communication user is that Inbound Communication User created in Step B.4.   The newly created Source System is S4-myxxxxx-source-joule. 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud as a New Source System in the SAP CIS

When you create a new Target System, make sure your Source System is S4-myxxxxx-source-joule, the one you just created as shown below.  They work in tandem.

The Work Zone as a New Target System in the SAP CIS

Since the Target System is the Work Zone, we need to use the user information stored in Work Zone instance of the BTP (referring Step A.7).

If you don‚Äôt have the Service Key file, follow this path: BTP -> Your Subaccount -> Services -> Instances and Subscriptions -> Instances -> Instance  -> Your Work Zone Instance -> Service Keys, download the Service Key file.

The Discovery Zone has a good screenshot to map the Target System creation window and the Service Key file content.  If the picture is too blurry, download it, then enlarge it to be readable!!! It is my tip of the day üòâ.

 

Step B.8 DC2: Provision Users and Groups from S/4HANA Cloud to Work Zone

After above Steps B.5 ‚Äì B.7, we are ready to provision user and group information from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Source System) to the Work Zone instance (Target System).  This step uses the Identity Provision Service (IPS) function within the SAP CIS.

 

Step B.9 DC2: Validate User Provisioning in SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

Besides checking the Provisioning Log in Step B.8, you can also check the results of this provisioning work by doing the following: BTP  -> Your Subaccount  -> Services  -> Instances and Subscriptions  -> Subscriptions  -> Application  -> clicking the hyperlink of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.  The Work Zone Site Manage window is launched.

From Content Manager, you can see all the groups provisioned.  The covered text string in the ID Column is the Content Provider ID we explored in above Step B.3.  For example, the ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR indicates the role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is from Content Provider xxxxyyy. 

Viewing the Provisioned User Roles/Groups in the Work Zone Content Manager

If you click on the ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR, it reveals the applications assigned to this Role ID.

Apps Assigned to the Role ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

By clicking on the Settings  -> Identity Provisioning, we can see the individual user information.  The covered text string in the Role ID Column or the Provider ID Column is the Work Zone Content Provider ID we explored in Step B.3.  In other words, these roles are effective in the mentioned Work Zone.

Viewing the Individual User and the Assigned Groups in the Settings -> Identity Provisioning

These two roles match what I have in the Public Cloud as shown below.

Two Business Roles Assigned to My Account

 

Step B.10 Test Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

This is an exciting step of your entire setup journey.

As you can see from my above screens, I only have two Administrator authorizations in this setup. When I open the Joule, it suggests the apps based on my role, such as ‚ÄúFind Security Audit Log Apps‚Äù. After I click on it, it did the job for me.

Joule‚Äôs Suggestion base on My User Roles

 

Joule Helped Me to Open the Security Audit Log

There are two possible issues you might face:

  1. You don‚Äôt see the Joule icon after you setup Joule for the first time. This happens quite often. Don‚Äôt worry and it might be caused by old caches in your Web Browser. Try to open an Incognico or Private window and launch your SAP S/4HANA Cloud. If the Joule icon is there, you are good. You can delete old caches in your regular web browser.
  2. You cannot display the Sales Order list in the Joule. Most probably you don‚Äôt have the right authorizations.  You should fail at launching any sales order related apps as well as shown below.  Give yourself the right user roles, and re-provision the users from S/4HANA Cloud to the Work Zone as described in Step B.8.

Failed to ‚ÄúShow Sales Orders‚Äù due to Authorization Limit to the User

 

Conclusion

In this blog, I explained reasons and catches of all the steps outlined in the Discovery Center 1 Establish a Unified Joule Instance and Discovery Center 2 Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, focusing on the steps running the Joule Booster and post-processes. By following some tips outlined, I hope you can reach your end zone with no or less troubles.

  2. Blog 2: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide

entry.title: Shift identity management from SAP IDM to SAP IAG with CIS and GRC AC.
entry.content:
Disclaimer-It is recommended to conduct an SAP IDM assessment to evaluate the feasibility of migrating existing functionalities to SAP IAG, CIS, or GRC Access Control. The approach in this blog is particularly suitable for customers who primarily use SAP IDM for managing access in SAP systems, whether on-premise or in the cloud.In a more complex and heterogeneous enterprise-wide environment, customers are most likely to rely on a third-party identity management solution. Refer this blog that highlights our partnership with Microsoft to position MS Entra as a successor for SAP IDM.

SAP provides a comprehensive suite of identity and access management (IAM) solutions to help customers manage user identities across their SAP applications, both on-premise and in the cloud. These solutions include SAP Identity Management (SAP IDM), SAP GRC Access Control (SAP GRC AC), SAP Cloud Identity Services (comprising Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning), and the SAP Identity Access Governance (SAP IAG) service.

SAP IDM, the long-standing on-premise IAM solution that has supported customers for over two decades, is approaching the end of its maintenance lifecycle (refer to SAP Note 3268799). Organizations currently using SAP IDM and planning a migration strategy can consider leveraging SAP IAG, SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS), and their existing SAP GRC Access Control systems to cover identity lifecycle management needs. In many cases, the combination of SAP IAG with CIS‚Äîor SAP IAG with CIS and a bridge to SAP GRC Access Control‚Äîcan replicate most of the functionalities previously handled by SAP IDM.

SAP IAG and SAP CIS are designed to complement each other and are often deployed together in enterprise environments to deliver end-to-end identity and access management. Additionally, SAP IAG can be integrated in a bridge scenario with SAP GRC Access Control to reuse existing configurations and ensure a smooth transition.

entry.title: Developing a SAP FSM extension on SAP BTP CF using Federated Authentication
entry.content:
This article details a step-by-step guide for developing an SAP Field Service Management (FSM) extension on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry (CF) with federated authentication.

It is not intended to be a "Best Practices" document, but rather a simple reference. Because it does not cover a wide number of potential scenarios, it should be considered just a starting point.

 

The use case.

When it comes to ‚ÄúAuthentication‚Äù, to my experience, one of the first errors made when developing an extension for SAP Field Service (FSM) on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry (CF), is to assume that since both are SAP products, authentication is implicit. Although it is reasonable way of thinking, it is not true.

Unfortunately, we learn very late, and the hardest way, that such an assumption is incorrect. Commonly, it happens when we have already generated the extension, it has an XSUAA (Extended Services for User Authentication and Authorization) enabled, and we are already trying to install it via the app SAP FSM Extension Management... just at the time the application throws an error that the extension is invalid.

After multiple attempts without figuring out what's going on, we probably will end up contacting SAP support. In most cases, they will recommend checking the Authentication section on the official SAP documentation portal or suggesting that the extension should be made publicly available on the internet. Which is often misinterpreted as a "please disable XSUAA" üò≥

It's at this very moment where it looks like we're going to a dead-end road: if we enable XSUAA, we cannot install the extension. If we disable it, then our extension could be accessed from the internet by anyone. Additionally, looking at the official SAP documentation reveals there are several ways to achieve authentication, but none of them seem to align with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry (CF) üò•. Perhaps with frustration, we wonder if there is a way to get authenticated only in the FSM Shell, and then have the rest happen with Single Sign-On (SSO).

 

The solution.

In an scenario SAP FSM <--> SAP BTP CF, is possible logging in the SAP FSM Shell (only once) and letting the rest happen with Single Sign-On (SSO). This, thanks to the SAP IAS (Cloud Identity Services), which is a core component of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that provides authentication services and identity management in the cloud.

This blog describes the journey step by step, from developing the extension to configuring the Federated Authentication in SAP FSM, SAP IAS, and SAP BTP.

Before getting started, it's necessary to check the following prerequisites:

  • You have SAPUI5 development expertise: Advanced skills are not required but a basic level would be very helpful. You can find a variety of resources on the official website.
  • You have an account on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP): If you don‚Äôt have an account, follow this tutorial.
  • You have an account on SAP Field Service Management.
  • You know the SAP Business Application Studio (BAS): Check out the official documentation or join the community.
  • You have set up the SAP Business Application Studio for development: If you have not set it up yet, follow this tutorial.
  • You have a DEV space up and running: If you have not created a DEV space yet, follow this tutorial.

This article is divided into five parts:

  • The development of the extension. Based on SAP Fiori design and SAP UI5.
  •  Integrating the SAP FSM ShellSDK library, which allows interaction between the extension and the SAP FSM Shell.
  • Configuring the Federated Authentication (using OIDC) between SAP FSM, SAP AIS, and SAP BTP.
  • The build and deployment in SAP BTP.
  • The installation process in SAP FSM.

 

Developing the Extension

a. In the DEV space in your SAP BTP Business Application Studio, choose New Project from Template:

b. Select SAP Fiori generator and choose Start:

c. Select Basic from the list of templates and choose Next:

d. Select None from the data source dropdown and choose Next:

e. Leave the default view name and choose Next:

f. Enter the module name, application title, description, and select Yes from the Add deployment configuration options. Then, choose Next:

g. Select Cloud Foundry from the target dropdown and select Yes from the Add application to managed application router options. Then, choose Finish:

h. In the workspace dialog box, choose Add project to workspace:

 

Integrating the SAP FSM ShellSDK library

a. To integrate the SAP FSM Shell SDK library into the extension, it is necessary to load it during the startup (for more information, see ShellSdk Examples). In your extension project, enhance the file /ui5extension/webapp/Component.js with the following code:

// Shell SDK library
sap.ui.loader.config({
    paths: {
        "sap/coresystems/fsm-shell": "https://unpkg.com/fsm-shell@1.20.0/release/fsm-shell-client"
    },
    shim: {
        "sap/coresystems/fsm-shell": {
            amd: true,
            exports: "FSMShell"
        }
    },
    async: true
});

b. Initialize the client by sending a REQUIRE_CONTEXT event to the SAP Shell SDK Host. For more information, see ShellSdk - Library usage sample. Adapt the generated code in the  file /ui5extension/webapp/controller/View1.controller.js, so it looks as follows:

sap.ui.define([
...
    "sap/coresystems/fsm-shell"
...

return Controller.extend("ui5extension.controller.View1", {
    onInit: function () {

        const { ShellSdk, SHELL_EVENTS } = FSMShell;

        const shellSdk = ShellSdk.init(parent, '*');

        shellSdk.emit(SHELL_EVENTS.Version1.REQUIRE_CONTEXT, {
            clientIdentifier: 'fsm-demo-plugin',
        });

...

c. To display some extracted data from SAP FSM, enrich the generated content in the file /ui5extension/webapp/view/View1.view.xml with the following code:

...
        <content>
            <sap.ui.layout:Grid xmlns:sap.ui.layout="sap.ui.layout" id="grid0">
                <sap.ui.layout:content>
                    <ObjectListItem title="account" intro="Account" icon="sap-icon://account" id="account"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="accountID" intro="Account ID" icon="sap-icon://account" id="accountID"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="company" intro="Company" icon="sap-icon://factory" id="company"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="companyID" intro="Company ID" icon="sap-icon://factory" id="companyID"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="user" intro="User" icon="sap-icon://account" id="user"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="userID" intro="User ID" icon="sap-icon://account" id="userID"/>
                    <ObjectListItem title="locale" intro="Selected Locale" icon="sap-icon://globe" id="selLocale"/>
                </sap.ui.layout:content>
            </sap.ui.layout:Grid>
        </content>
...

d. Adjust the controller /ui5extension/webapp/controller/View1.controller.js by adding the following code:

...
...
  const oView = this.getView();
...
...
  
  shellSdk.on(SHELL_EVENTS.Version1.REQUIRE_CONTEXT, (event) => {
    const {
      account,
      accountId,
      company,
      companyId,
      user,
      userId,
      selectedLocale,
    } = JSON.parse(event);

    oView.byId("account").setTitle(account);
    oView.byId("accountID").setTitle(accountId);
    oView.byId("company").setTitle(company);
    oView.byId("companyID").setTitle(companyId);
    oView.byId("user").setTitle(user);
    oView.byId("userID").setTitle(userId);
    oView.byId("selLocale").setTitle(selectedLocale);
   });
...

 

Configure Authentication

a. In your extension project, create a file appconfig.json under ./ui5extension/webapp/. This concept is described in the SAP FSM Documentation.

{
    "name": "SAP FSM UI5 Extension",
    "provider": "SAP FSM",
    "description": "SAP FSM UI5 Extension",
    "version": "1.0.0", 
    "icon": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SAP-samples/fsm-extension-sample/refactor/samples/login-with-token/frontend/icon.png"
}

b. In the file xs-app.json, disable the xsuaa for the file appconfig.json as follows:

{
    "welcomeFile": "/index.html",
    "authenticationMethod": "route",
    "routes": [
    {
        "source": "^/resources/(.*)$",
        "target": "/resources/$1",
        "authenticationType": "none",
        "destination": "ui5"
    },
    {
        "source": "^/test-resources/(.*)$",
        "target": "/test-resources/$1",
        "authenticationType": "none",
        "destination": "ui5"
    },
    {
        "source": "^/appconfig\\.json$",
        "target": "/appconfig.json",
        "service": "html5-apps-repo-rt",
        "authenticationType": "none",
        "cacheControl": "no-cache"
    },
    {
        "source": "^(.*)$",
        "target": "$1",
        "service": "html5-apps-repo-rt",
        "authenticationType": "xsuaa"
    }]
}

c. Get a SAP Cloud Identity Service Tenant:

  • In the SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your sub-account Entitlements and check if you have an item Cloud Identity Services. If you don‚Äôt have it, choose Edit, then Add Service Plans. In the pop-up search for Cloud Identity Services, select the default service plan, and then choose Add Service Plan. Finally, save the changes on the Entitlements page:

  • Navigate to Services, then to Service Marketplace and select the item Cloud Identity Services. On the top-right corner, in the Meatball men√∫ of the tile [...], choose Create.

  • In the pop-up, from the Service dropdown list select Cloud Identity Services. From the Plan drop down list select default. Then choose Next:

  • Leave the Instance parameters as Form (default value), and from the Service Type dropdown list select the value that suits your use case. For this blog, I have chosen Test.

  • Choose Next, review the configuration and choose Create.

  • After a short while, a subscription to the SAP Cloud Identity Service Tenant should appear in the list of Services ==> Instances and Subscriptions, in the SAP BTP Cockpit. You should also receive an email to confirm your account for the Administration Console of the Identity Authentication Service.

d. Set the Trust and Federation between the SAP Authorization and Trust Management Service and the SAP Cloud Identity Service:

  • In the SAP BTP cockpit, under Security ==> Trust Configuration choose Establish Trust.

  • In the pop-up choose the SAP Cloud Identity Service Tenant, then choose Next.

  • Choose the domain configured with the SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant and continue with Next.

  • If needed, change the name, description, origin key, and link text for user logon of the tenant. Otherwise leave it as proposed by the wizard and continue with Next.

  • Review the configuration and choose Finish.

  • Set to inactive the Default Identity Provider: select the action item from the list, in the details panel choose Edit, uncheck the option Available for user Logon, then choose Save

e. Configure the Federated Authentication with OpenID Connect (OIDC), as described in the SAP FSM Documentation.

1. Register your SAP FSM Account as an Application in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Tenant:

- Open the IAS Admin UI, go to Applications & Resources, choose create, add a new entry as follows, then choose create:

- In the new Application, navigate to the section Single Sign-On ==> OpenID Connect Configuration. Choose a Name, maintain the Redirect URI, and choose Save.

The URIs depend on the SAP FSM cluster:

DE: https://de.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

AU: https://au.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

IE: https://eu.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

US: https://us.fsm.cloud.sap/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

CN: https://cn.fsm.sapcloud.cn/api/oauth2/v2/authorize

- In the new Application, navigate to the section Single Sign-On ==> Subject Name Identifier. In the Primary Attribute Choose Email, and then choose Save:

2. Create an OIDC Configuration (SAP IAS and SAP FSM)

- In the IAS Admin UI, navigate to the new Application, then to the section Application APIs ==> Client Authentication ==> Secrets, choose add, maintain the new secret as shown below, then save.

Make sure you keep a copy of the generated Client ID and the Client Secret in your favorite notepad:

- In the IAS Admin UI, navigate to Applications & Resources ==> Tenant Settings, then go to the section Single Sign-On ==> OpenID Connect Configuration. From the details, go to the section Identity Provider Settings and copy the following Endpoints in your favorite notepad:

- Authorization Endpoint

- Token Endpoint

- Logout Endpoint

- Login to the SAP Field Service Management Admin App with your account. Make sure you have enough rights to maintain configurations.

- Go to your account details, navigate to OpenID Connect Configuration, then create a configuration as follows:

- Name: any name of your choice

- IDP Client ID: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- IDP Client Secret: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- Authorization Endpoint URL: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- Token Endpoint URL: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- End Session Endpoint URL: the one copied from the SAP IAS Admin UI

- Fixed Redirect URI: the one used in the OpenID Connect Configuration in the SAP IAS Admin UI

3. Configure OIDC as the default Authentication Method for your SAP FSM Account:

In the SAP Field Service Management Admin App, navigate to your account details, choose Edit, then scroll down to the section Security, in OpenID Connect Configuration choose the one created previously, and then choose Update:

4. Test your configuration:

- Have a "testing user" in your SAP IAS Tenant which is active and has the email address confirmed:

- Have the same "testing user" active in SAP Field Service Management with the same email as the one created in the SAP IAS tenant. The email address should be assigned only to this user, and the role SUPERUSER should be also assigned.

- Visit the SAP FSM Shell login page https://de.fsm.cloud.sap/shell/#/login, type in your account, then choose Continue.

- You should be redirected to the Identity Provider. Type in the email address of the "testing user", the corresponding password, and choose Continue.

- You should login to SAP Field Service Management.

5. In your sub-account in the SAP BTP Cockpit, navigate to Security ==> Settings, then to Trusted Domains, choose Add to register the domain of the Cluster where your SAP FSM account exists. For example, for DE it should be https://de.fsm.cloud.sap 

 

Build, Deploy, and Test the Extension

a. Build: in the SAP Business Application Studio right click over the file ./ui5extension/mta.yaml and choose Build MTA. Once the building is finished, the folders ./ui5extension/dist and ./ui5extension/mta_archives/ should be generated.

b. Deploy: right click on the file ./ui5extension/mta_archives/ui5extension_0.0.1.mtar and choose Deploy MTA Archive.

c. Test: make sure you have a subscription to an "application plan" of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition in the SAP BTP Cockpit:

Click on the extension:

It should open the SAP UI5 application (the extension) in a new browser. Make sure you copy the url in your favorite notepad, you will need it during the installation process in the app SAP FSM Extension Management.

Note that if you are using chrome, if you open the URL of the extension in a new browser in Incognito Mode, you should be redirected to the Identity Provider where you need to type in the email address of the "testing user", as well as the corresponding password. Then the SAP UI5 application should look like this:

 

Registering the extension in SAP FSM

a. Login to your SAP FSM account with your "testing user". From the Shell home screen, navigate to the Foundational Services app, then to Extensions ==> Installed, and choose Add Extension.

b. When asked for the Access URL, use the one copied in your favorite notepad while testing the extension on SAP BTP, then choose Next.

Make sure you remove the ending index.html from the URL. It should look something like this:

c. The extension details should be pulled from the appconfig.json provided in the extension. Choose Next Step:

d. Finish the installation process by following the next steps. For more information, see Manually Installing an Extension.

e. Assign the extension to the outlet position of your preference. For more information, see Placing an Extension.

The extension should be shown and it should have not required any extra authentication:

entry.title: How IAS and IPS Help Secure SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Hey SAP Community! If you're like me, you're always trying to make business apps easier and safer to use. Today, I want to chat about two tools that help with that: Identity Authentication Service (IAS) and Identity Provisioning Service (IPS). They‚Äôre big players in SAP, especially for managing users in SAP SuccessFactors. But what do they actually do, and why should you care? Let‚Äôs break it down!

What is IAS?

Think of IAS like the front door to your apps. It makes sure only the right people get in. IAS helps you by letting users log in once and access everything they need without logging in again (that's called single sign-on or SSO). Plus, you get to pick how users log in, whether it‚Äôs with a password, a social media account, or even using two steps for extra security.

Cool Things IAS Can Do:

  • Easy Login (SSO): Users love not having to log in over and over on different apps. It's super convenient.
  • Extra Security: You can require more login checks based on who the user is or where they are logging in from. This keeps your apps safe.
  • Works with Other Services: Got Microsoft Azure Active Directory? No worries. IAS can talk to these outside services so everything works together smoothly.
  • Manage Setup with API: Using the tech behind IAS, you spend less time tweaking settings and more time using your apps.

IAS is like the guard at the entrance, keeping everything secure without making it complicated.

Getting to Know IPS

Now onto IPS! It‚Äôs not just a fancy name. If IAS is the front door, IPS is the key that makes sure everyone has the right access. It makes managing user identities simple across both cloud systems and systems running internally on your company's hardware.

Cool Things IPS Can Do:

  • User Management: IPS jumps in after you're set up with IAS to ensure everyone gets the right access on all platforms. Think of it like your personal assistant for user access.
  • Data Control: You don‚Äôt need all data everywhere. With IPS, you can control what goes where and tailor it to your needs.
  • Transparency and Notifications: IPS keeps you informed with logs and notifications about what's happening with user provisioning. You always know what's going on.

 

 

 

IPS works quietly behind the scenes, giving users access smoothly without manual hassle.

Why IAS and IPS Matter

You might be thinking, "Do I really need these services?" Absolutely, yes! SAP wants to make sure identity authentication is simple and pre-configured in their systems. This means less worry about user access.

IAS can also manage other identity providers, integrating them easily into your workflows. You get strong security and ease in one package.

Setting Up IAS/IPS

Wondering how to set this up? You‚Äôre not alone. IAS/IPS comes with many SAP cloud services, but you can also set them up through SAP Business Technology Platform. The best place to start is SAP's Tenant Discovery link to see if you have them ready.

Customizing and Using IAS/IPS

After setup, you can customize login pages, email templates, and usage terms. Check out SAP‚Äôs help documents for detailed guides on making the most of IAS/IPS:

  • Identity Authentication Help Documents
  • Identity Provisioning Help Documents

 

Wrapping Up

So there you have it, a simple look at why IAS and IPS are key for SAP SuccessFactors and other SAP cloud systems. They make life easier for you and your users, ensuring smooth and secure access. I hope this helps you understand these great tools better. Until next time, keep your identities safe and your systems secure!

entry.title: SAP Business Technology Platform(BTP) Security Best Practices: Expert Tips to Protect Your Platform
entry.content:
Heard about those big cyber-attacks recently? No names needed, but chances are, your weekly shop has been hit. The interesting thing is that they followed a familiar pattern. Security analysts found that over 52,000 new vulnerabilities were disclosed in 2024, indicating that outdated or misconfigured systems are a growing invitation to attackers (sentinelone.com). Hackers often slip in via a ‚Äòside door‚Äô: an unpatched server, an ill-configured cloud service, or a tricked user giving up a password. Another analysis of supply-chain incidents found that about half were driven by stolen or weak credentials (securityinfowatch.com). In plain terms, cybercrooks lean on low-hanging fruit - phishing, reused passwords, forgotten updates , more than any sci-fi-style hack.

Naturally, this has SAP customers asking: ‚ÄúAre our own SAP BTP environments secure? Is our user management tight? Are we following cloud security best practices?‚Äù These are great questions, and we‚Äôve been hearing them a lot. So in this blog post we tried to answer these burning questions. We will address everything from locking down user accounts to broader security best practices, and we promise it won‚Äôt be a parade of jargon or doom-and-gloom. 

What can we learn from the recent cyber-attacks in the UK?

The recent cyber-attacks targeting major UK retailers mark a significant moment in cyber security as these are among the first Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks to penetrate networks that were protected by enterprise-grade firewalls. In many cases, these firewalls are managed by hyper scalars such as AWS, Microsoft Azure, or Google Cloud, who provide the foundational infrastructure.

However, it‚Äôs important to recognise that responsibility for security is shared. There‚Äôs a fine line between what the hyper scaler secures and what platform providers, like SAP BTP or Microsoft Power Platform, are responsible for. Most organisations today operate across multiple platforms, each with its own security model, tools, and SLAs, which can lead to gaps in the overall defence posture if not carefully managed.

It‚Äôs also a reminder of the real-world consequences of cybersecurity failures. When breaches occur, especially those involving customer data, organisations face not just supply chain or reputational damage, but significant financial penalties under regulations like GDPR. We‚Äôve seen this play out repeatedly, including with major social media companies in recent years.

These all point to the importance of a well-coordinated, multi-layered security approach. It‚Äôs got to be holistic and span infrastructure, platforms, and application layers, with clear roles and responsibilities.

How secure is SAP BTP out of the box, and what are the most common gaps you see in customer configurations?

So, that‚Äôs the approach, but how is this carried out? The Business Technology Platform is designed with security and governance in mind across multiple layers. Out of the box, SAP BTP offers:

  • Built‚Äëin Identity & Access Management (IAM) & Network Security: Native support for Single Sign On(SSO) /Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), Role Based Access Control(RBAC), and the SAP Authorisation Management service. Only authorised users and roles can access each sub-account or application.
  • Encryption & Transport Security: All user traffic is TLS-encrypted , and SAP exclusively establishes encrypted communication channels by default.
  • Monitoring & Audit: SAP BTP automatically logs admin and user activities. The Cloud Foundry Audit Log Viewer service lets you review all operations (applications created, users added, etc.), and connect these logs as desired.
  • Secure Development Tools: SAP‚Äôs Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and other frameworks include built-in security guards (XSRF tokens, JWT checks, etc.), plus tools like the SAP Code Vulnerability Analyser (CVA) that statically scan ABAP code on SAP BTP before deployment.

However, despite this strong foundation, we often see gaps in how customers configure their environments. The most common issues include:

  • Bypassing SAP BTP Connectivity Guidelines‚Ä®Customers sometimes integrate third-party APIs or services directly, without using the secure connectivity mechanisms provided by SAP BTP. This can create vulnerabilities and reduce visibility over traffic flows.
  • Improper Credential Management‚Ä®Instead of using SAP BTP‚Äôs built-in credential stores, credentials are sometimes hardcoded or stored in less secure ways, leaving applications open to compromise.
  • Neglecting Secure App Design Principles‚Ä®Applications are not always developed using the security best practices. This can lead to poor access controls, exposure to common vulnerabilities, or lack of proper authorisation checks.

While SAP BTP provides a secure foundation, maintaining a strong security posture requires careful configuration and adherence to recommended best practices, particularly when it comes to connectivity, credential management, and application architecture.

How to prevent similar attacks when running business-critical workloads on SAP BTP?

To safeguard business-critical workloads on SAP BTP, a few key practices should be followed:

  • Use SAP Services for All Integrations: Ensure every integration and API call goes through SAP‚Äôs connectivity and security layers. Use the SAP Destination Service, API Management, and the Cloud Connector/Connectivity Service, rather than hard‚Äëcoding endpoints. This way, TLS is enforced and flows are logged and constrained. (Think of SAP BTP services like a secure gateway that you should not bypass.)
  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication Everywhere: Require MFA for all user logins ‚Äì not just admins. SAP Cloud Identity Service (or your corporate IdP) can enforce MFA policies on every SAP BTP access. SAP‚Äôs TechEd guide even walks through configuring MFA for SAP BTP apps. This means stolen passwords alone won‚Äôt give attackers an easy in.
  • Harden IAM and Accounts: Follow the principle of least privilege. Regularly audit user roles and prune any unused or generic accounts. Disable any unused features like self-registration or social sign-on. Use roles and groups in your Identity Provider (IdP) to ensure people only get the permissions needed for their job.
  • Monitor and Respond to Logs: Subscribing to the SAP Audit Log Viewer (for Cloud Foundry (CF)) is critical. Review logs periodically for anomalies (e.g. logins from new locations, sudden privilege grants). Configure alerts or integrate these logs into your Security Information & Event Management(SIEM). Quick detection can stop an incident in its tracks.

Even doing just these steps drastically cuts risk. In effect, you‚Äôre closing the ‚Äòside doors‚Äô: every inbound or outbound connection is tracked by SAP, every user action is logged, and strong authentication blocks the common tricks that took down those retailers.

What role does identity and access management play in defending against modern cyber threats in SAP environments?

Identity and Access Management (IAM) is the keystone of SAP BTP security. SAP BTP supports a full identity lifecycle and fine-grained authorisation model:

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): You define roles or role collections in your SAP BTP sub-accounts (and business roles in the ABAP environment) that grant only needed permissions. Then you assign these roles to users/groups. This enforces least privilege, so even if a user‚Äôs credentials are compromised, the attacker‚Äôs access is limited.
  • Trusted Identity Providers: BTP can federate with SAP Cloud Identity (Identity Authentication Service) or any SAML/OAuth IdP. Once trust is set up, employees authenticate with corporate credentials (with MFA, if you‚Äôve enforced it). This ensures a single point of control over user accounts and policies. IAM integrates with identity providers and defines roles and permissions to secure applications and data.
  • Principal Propagation: When a user calls between SAP systems (for example, a CF app calling an ABAP endpoint), their identity and roles ‚Äútravel‚Äù with the request. This maintains security boundaries across services.

IAM practices help organisations enforce strict access boundaries, maintain compliance, and defend against unauthorised access‚Äîwhether from external attackers or internal misconfigurations.

How can organisations balance innovation on SAP BTP with the need for robust security and compliance?

Innovation and security are not opposing forces‚Äîthey must evolve together. As applications built on SAP BTP grow in complexity, the security measures surrounding them must also mature. The more advanced and interconnected your solutions become, the greater the need for enhanced controls, monitoring, and governance.

Organisations that fail to innovate risk becoming obsolete. But equally, those that innovate without embedding strong security and compliance practices expose themselves to serious vulnerabilities. Every new capability, integration, or user touchpoint introduces potential risks that must be addressed as part of the innovation lifecycle.

Training is also key. Ensure developers and admins know SAP BTP best practices. Ignorance may be bliss, but it also breeds vulnerabilities, since human error is often the weakest link. If all personal interacting with the platform are aware of the threats, they can help mitigate them but also spot them. Make security part of your culture and process ‚Äì every innovation needs to come with corresponding security guardrails.

Sustainable innovation on SAP BTP requires a security-first mindset‚Äîwhere governance, compliance, and threat prevention are integrated into every phase of development and deployment.

Securing your innovation on SAP BTP

The recent cyber-attacks serve as a stark reminder that even the most well-defended systems are not immune to evolving and opportunistic threats. For organisations leveraging SAP BTP to drive innovation, the message is clear: security must be treated as a continuous discipline, not a one-time checklist.

While SAP BTP provides a strong out-of-the-box security framework, real resilience comes from how that framework is implemented, monitored, and adapted. From enforcing secure connectivity and managing access intelligently, to following coding best practices and monitoring audit logs‚Äîevery detail matters.

To conclude, the balance between innovation and security is not a compromise; it‚Äôs a partnership. With the right governance, identity management, and adherence to best practices, organisations can confidently build and scale on SAP BTP‚Äîwithout sacrificing trust, compliance, or control.

Please feel free to share your experiences and thoughts on the similar approaches you might have taken securing your applications on SAP BTP in the comments section.

This course provides the key concepts, practical insights, and technical guidance you need to design and maintain a secure SAP BTP environment. You‚Äôll gain a solid foundation in managing identity, authentication, authorization, and secure connectivity ‚Äî all within the context of SAP BTP.

What You'll Learn

entry.title: User Login for External Apps with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Introduction

For developers in the SAP BTP ecosystem, the standard path for authentication involves the SAP Application Router and XSUAA. It's robust and deeply integrated. But what if you need to connect a non-BTP application or simply want to experiment with open standards?

This guide demonstrates how to authenticate a standalone Node.js application directly against SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) using a standard OpenID Connect (OIDC) flow.

Disclaimer: A Proof-of-Concept, Not a Production BTP Recipe

It's crucial to state this upfront: this approach is for educational and validation purposes. For production applications on SAP BTP, the Approuter/XSUAA model remains the recommended best practice. This method is perfect for learning, prototyping, or integrating external apps.

Part 1: Prerequisites - Setting up SAP CIS and Your Local Environment

Before we write any code, we need to configure our identity provider (CIS) and prepare our local machine.

Step 1: Subscribe to Cloud Identity Services

First, ensure you have a subscription to the Cloud Identity Services application in your BTP subaccount. You can add it via the "Service Marketplace" if you haven't already.

Step 2: Create an OIDC Application in SAP CIS

Navigate to your SAP CIS tenant's administration console. You can typically access this from the "Instances and Subscriptions" page in your BTP subaccount.

  1. In the CIS admin UI, go to Applications & Resources -> Applications.
  2. Click Create Application.
  3. Fill in the application details:
    • Name: localhost-auth-app (or any name you prefer)
    • Protocol: Select OpenID Connect from the dropdown.
       
  4. Add redirect URL.
    This will reveal the OIDC-specific configuration options. For now, we'll set placeholder values for the URIs.
    • Redirect URIs: https://localhost:3000/callback
    • Web Origins: https://localhost:3000
    • Click Save

Step 3: Collect Your Credentials and Issuer URL

Once the application is saved, CIS will generate the necessary credentials. Keep this page open or copy the following values to a safe place:

  • Client ID: A long, unique string.
  • Client Secret: Click the "show secret" icon to reveal and copy it.

    Next, you need the Issuer URL. This is the unique URL for your CIS tenant that OIDC clients use for discovery.

    1. In the CIS admin UI, navigate to Tenant Settings -> OpenID Connect Configuration.
    2. Under Identity Provider Settings, you will find the Issuer URL.

Copy this URL. It will look something like https://.trial-accounts.ondemand.com. For example: https://afsp7XXXX.trial-accounts.ondemand.com.

Step 4: Create a Self-Signed Certificate for Local HTTPS

Our Node.js application will run locally on https://localhost.

To enable HTTPS, which is required for OIDC flows, we need an SSL certificate. We can generate a self-signed one for development purposes using OpenSSL.

Open your terminal and run this command:

# This command creates a key.pem and cert.pem file valid for 365 days.
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -nodes -sha256 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -days 365

You will be prompted to enter some information. You can press Enter to accept the defaults. This will generate key.pem and cert.pem in your current directory.

Part 2: Building the Node.js Application

Now we're ready to build the app.

Step 1: Project Setup

Create a new project folder and initialize it.

# Create project directory and navigate into it
mkdir cis-oidc-app && cd cis-oidc-app

# Initialize a Node.js project
npm init -y

# Install necessary libraries
npm install express openid-client@5.1.5 dotenv

# Create our application files
touch app.js .env

Note: We are pinning openid-client to a known stable version (5.1.5) to avoid potential issues with newer releases.

Step 2: Configure Environment Variables

Open the .env file and add the credentials you collected from CIS.

# .env file

# Paste the Issuer URL from your CIS tenant's OIDC settings
CIS_ISSUER_URL="https://afsp7XXXX.trial-accounts.ondemand.com"

# Paste the Client ID from your created application in CIS
CLIENT_ID="your-client-id-from-cis"

# Paste the Client Secret from your created application in CIS
CLIENT_SECRET="your-client-secret-from-cis"

# The port our local server will run on
PORT=3000

Step 3: The Complete, Working Code (app.js)

This is the full code. The key fix for the openid.Issuer is not a constructor error is using await Issuer.discover() instead of the old constructor method.

require('dotenv').config();
const express = require('express');
const https = require('https');
const fs = require('fs');
const { Issuer } = require('openid-client');

const app = express();
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;

// Environment variables check
console.log('Checking environment variables:');
console.log('CIS_ISSUER_URL:', process.env.CIS_ISSUER_URL);
console.log('CLIENT_ID:', process.env.CLIENT_ID);
console.log('CLIENT_SECRET:', process.env.CLIENT_SECRET ? '*** (configured)' : 'not set');
console.log('PORT:', process.env.PORT);

// HTTPS options
const httpsOptions = {
  key: fs.readFileSync('key.pem'),
  cert: fs.readFileSync('cert.pem')
};

// Custom Issuer configuration for trial account
async function getCustomIssuer() {
  try {
    console.log('Fetching Issuer configuration...');
    
    const issuer = await Issuer.discover(process.env.CIS_ISSUER_URL);
    console.log('Issuer configuration successful:', issuer.issuer);
    
    return issuer;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Issuer configuration error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
}

// OIDC client initialization
async function initOIDCClient() {
  try {
    const issuer = await getCustomIssuer();
    
    const client = new issuer.Client({
      client_id: process.env.CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.CLIENT_SECRET,
      redirect_uris: [`https://localhost:${port}/callback`],
      response_types: ['code'],
      token_endpoint_auth_method: 'client_secret_basic'
    });
    
    console.log('OIDC client initialized successfully');
    return client;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Client initialization error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
}

// Authentication flow
app.get('/login', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    console.log('Starting login process...');
    const client = await initOIDCClient();
    const authUrl = client.authorizationUrl({
      scope: 'openid profile email',
      redirect_uri: `https://localhost:${port}/callback`
    });
    
    console.log('Generated authentication URL:', authUrl);
    res.redirect(authUrl);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Login error:', error);
    res.status(500).send(`Initialization error: ${error.message}`);
  }
});

// Callback processing
app.get('/callback', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    console.log('Callback received');
    const client = await initOIDCClient();
    const params = client.callbackParams(req);
    
    console.log('Exchanging token...');
    const tokenSet = await client.callback(
      `https://localhost:${port}/callback`,
      params
    );
    
    console.log('Fetching user information...');
    const userInfo = await client.userinfo(tokenSet);
    console.log('User information retrieved:', userInfo.sub);
    
    res.send(`
      <!DOCTYPE html>
      <html lang="en">
      <head>
        <meta charset="UTF-8">
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
        <title>Authentication Successful</title>
        <style>
          body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.6; max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 20px; }
          h1 { color: #2e7d32; }
          pre { background: #f5f5f5; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; overflow-x: auto; }
          .user-info { background: #e8f5e9; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; margin-bottom: 20px; }
          .btn { display: inline-block; padding: 10px 20px; background: #4CAF50; color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 4px; }
        </style>
      </head>
      <body>
        <h1>Authentication Successful!</h1>
        
        <div class="user-info">
          <p><strong>Username:</strong> ${userInfo.name || userInfo.email}</p>
          <p><strong>User ID:</strong> ${userInfo.sub}</p>
        </div>
        
        <h2>User Information:</h2>
        <pre>${JSON.stringify(userInfo, null, 2)}</pre>
        
        <hr>
        <a class="btn" href="/">Back to Home</a>
      </body>
      </html>
    `);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Callback processing error:', error);
    res.status(500).send(`
      <h1>Authentication Error</h1>
      <p>${error.message}</p>
      <a href="/">Back to Home</a>
    `);
  }
});

// Home page
app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send(`
    <!DOCTYPE html>
    <html lang="en">
    <head>
      <meta charset="UTF-8">
      <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
      <title>SAP CIS Authentication Demo</title>
      <style>
        body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.6; max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 40px 20px; text-align: center; }
        h1 { color: #1565c0; }
        .container { background: #e3f2fd; padding: 30px; border-radius: 8px; }
        .btn { display: inline-block; padding: 12px 24px; background: #1565c0; color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 4px; font-size: 18px; margin-top: 20px; }
        .note { background: #fff8e1; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; margin-top: 30px; text-align: left; }
      </style>
    </head>
    <body>
      <div class="container">
        <h1>SAP CIS Authentication Demo</h1>
        <p>This demo shows how to authenticate with SAP Cloud Identity Services</p>
        <a class="btn" href="/login">Login with SAP CIS</a>
      </div>
      
      <div class="note">
        <h3>Browser Security Note:</h3>
        <p>If you see a security warning in your browser:</p>
        <ul>
          <li>Chrome: Type "thisisunsafe" in the address bar</li>
          <li>Others: Go to "Advanced Settings" ‚Üí "Proceed to localhost"</li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </body>
    </html>
  `);
});

// Development: Skip SSL certificate validation
process.env.NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED = '0';

// Start HTTPS server
https.createServer(httpsOptions, app).listen(port, () => {
  console.log('='.repeat(60));
  console.log(`App running: https://localhost:${port}`);
  console.log(`Login URL: https://localhost:${port}/login`);
  console.log('='.repeat(60));
  
  console.log('\n‚ö†Ô∏è Browser Access Instructions:');
  console.log('1. Go to "https://localhost:3000"');
  console.log('2. For security warnings:');
  console.log('   - Chrome: Type "thisisunsafe" in the address bar');
  console.log('   - Others: Click "Advanced" ‚Üí "Proceed to localhost"');
});

Step 4: Run the Application

You are now ready to test the entire flow.

  1. Run the server from your terminal:
    node app.js
  2. Open your browser and navigate to https://localhost:3000.
  3. Your browser will show a security warning because we are using a self-signed certificate. This is expected. Click "Advanced" and then "Proceed to localhost (unsafe)".
  4. Click the "Login with SAP CIS" link.
  5. You will be redirected to the SAP CIS login page. Enter your credentials.
  6. After successful login, you will be redirected back to your local application, which will display your user information.

Conclusion

This experiment successfully proves that SAP Cloud Identity Services is a fully compliant OIDC provider, capable of securing not just BTP-native applications but any external application that speaks open standards. While the Approuter/XSUAA pattern remains the gold standard for integrated BTP solutions, it's empowering to have this flexibility for prototyping and external integrations.

I hope this detailed guide helps you connect your own applications

In the second quarter of 2025, we released several new features and enhancements. Did you know that you can find all new feature announcements for SAP Cloud Identity Services in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes on the SAP Help Portal?

Identity Provisioning Service: Job log improvements

The Job Execution Outcome is now displayed on the Job Execution Details screen and included in the job notifications. It appears when delta-read jobs and jobs that fail to read entities from the source system affect the deletion of entities in the target system.
For more information, see Monitor Provisioning Job Logs.

You can now download and view the details of all deleted entities by a provisioning job. To enable this, set the property ips.trace.deleted.entity to true.
For more information, see Manage Provisioning Job Logs and List of Properties.

Identity Directory Service and Identity Provisioning Service: Support for extension schemas towards many SAP business applications

We now support a number of extension schemas, including

  • SAP extension schema for groups
  • Extension enterprise schema for users
  • SAP ODM User Schema Support

You can find details in the SAP Cloud Identity Release Notes.

Extension of the Identity Directory‚Äôs SCIM API

The Identity Directory API of SAP Cloud Identity Services now returns the termsOfUse and privacyPolicy parameters. For more information, check Identity Directory API.

In addition, we now support application-specific group assignments. You can find details in the SAP Help Portal chapters on Identity Authentication and the Local Identity Directory.

Management of Corporate Identity Providers via API

Tenant administrators can manage corporate identity providers in Identity Authentication via API. It offers endpoints for CRUD operations (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE) over the corporate identity providers. See SAP Cloud Identity Services Corporate Identity Providers Directory.

Configuration of Password Expiration Reminder

You can configure the system to show a password expiration reminder on the user‚Äôs sign-in page. For more information, check Enable Password Expiration Reminder.

Enabling SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI with support for Microsoft Windows mandatory profiles

We added support for single sign-on on shopfloor Windows-based computers that are configured to use a mandatory profile. This protects shopfloor computers with a restrictive mandatory profile while still offering single sign-on support for desktop clients of SAP GUI. You can find more information in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Cloud Foundry Login Based on JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)

When building CI/CD pipelines, developers are responsible for managing the credentials used by these pipelines for authentication to external systems. This traditionally requires developers to take care of the lifecycle of the credentials, including secure storage and regular rotation of the credentials, which comes with repeated efforts and might be error-prone.

In his latest blog post, Authenticating GitHub Actions Workflows Deploying to the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Environment with JWTs, Sebastian Ries explains how to authenticate to the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment from a GitHub Actions workflow using GitHub-issued short-lived JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), eliminating the need for manual secret management and enabling secure, efficient CI/CD workflows.
